The cold months have settled over Castile like a wool blanket drawn tight against the world. Snow dusts the Sierra de Gredos to the north, and ice forms nightly on the fountains of the Alcázar. Toledo's ancient streets grow quiet after vespers, its inhabitants retreating to hearths and braziers as the short days darken early.

The Royal Family is united in Toledo for the first time in years: Lucia (now Queen), Catalina (nearly three, speaking an endearing jumble of Castilian, Portuguese, and Italian), Fernando (sixteen months, walking now and getting into everything), and baby Bianca (three months old, a calm infant unlike her older siblings).

The meeting with Sultan Murad II at Tenedos is scheduled for spring—the most consequential diplomatic encounter of Juan's reign.

The first settler convoy to Constantinople must depart before summer winds make the voyage more difficult.

Álvaro de Luna is expected shortly to discuss the week's business. Diego de Daza has sent word that there are matters requiring attention regarding the infrastructure program. And there are dispatches from Isaac—always dispatches from Isaac now.


The kingdom turns slowly toward spring, and everything you have built waits to be tested.
